benchmark_details.name: QuRe (Quantifier Reasoning)
benchmark_details.overview: QuRe is a crowd-sourced dataset of human-annotated generalized quantifiers in Wikipedia sentences featuring percentage-equipped predicates. It is designed to evaluate the quantifier understanding capabilities of foundation models in natural language processing.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To investigate quantifier understanding in foundation models and provide a dataset for evaluating their capabilities.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: Despite the value of our dataset and the promising results from the PRESQUE framework, our analysis and findings have some notable limitations.

data.source: Crowd-sourced from Wikipedia sentences with percentage annotations.
data.annotation: Crowd-sourced via Amazon Mechanical Turk and hybrid annotations with GPT-3.5-turbo.

methodology.calculation: Metrics are calculated based on the comparison between predicted percentage scopes and the gold standard.
methodology.interpretation: Scores higher than the baseline indicate better quantifier understanding performance.
methodology.baseline_results: PRESQUE achieves better performance than L0 in several metrics including higher HIT@1 and lower cross-entropy.
methodology.validation: Validated through human evaluations and quantitative metrics on model performance.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: The dataset does not currently analyze demographic factors.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: No personally identifiable information about the annotators was collected.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.consent_procedures: All annotators were informed about the study and compensated fairly.
